title: 105_s1642
content:
The Act titled "Federal Financial Assistance Management Improvement Act of 1998" aims to streamline and simplify over 600 Federal financial assistance programs to improve the delivery of services to the public by reducing duplicative and burdensome administrative requirements. The Act aims to improve Federal financial assistance programs by enhancing effectiveness, simplifying application and reporting requirements, delivering services more efficiently, and promoting coordination among service providers. The Act defines key terms such as Director, Federal agency, Federal financial assistance, local government, non-Federal entity, and nonprofit organization. The term "nonprofit organization" refers to entities operated for public interest purposes without a primary focus on profit. The term "State" includes various governmental entities within the United States. The term "tribal government" pertains to Indian tribes as defined by federal law. A tribal government is defined as an Indian tribe under federal law. A uniform administrative rule is a government-wide rule for achieving national policy objectives across multiple federal financial assistance programs. SEC. 5. DUTIES OF FEDERAL AGENCIES. Each Federal agency must develop and implement a plan within 18 months of this Act that streamlines application procedures, demonstrates interagency participation, uses a common application system, designates a lead official, allows electronic applications, ensures timely reporting, and sets annual goals. The Act requires Federal agencies to provide high-quality information in response to reporting requirements and set annual goals. The Director may grant extensions for noncompliance, and agencies must publish their plans in the Federal Register for comment. Each Federal agency must publish their plan in the Federal Register for public comment and consultation with non-Federal entities. The lead official designated under subsection (a)(4) shall consult with representatives of State, local, and tribal governments. Agencies must submit the plan to the Director and Congress, reporting annually on its implementation and performance. The agency must report annually to the Director and Congress on the implementation of the plan and its performance in meeting specified goals. The report can be included in general management reports required by law. SEC. 6. DUTIES OF THE DIRECTOR. The Director, in consultation with agency heads and representatives of non-Federal entities, shall direct, coordinate, and assist Federal agencies in establishing a common application and reporting system for Federal financial assistance programs. This system includes a common application, electronic processes for managing funding, and uniform administrative rules across different Federal agencies. The Director may designate a lead agency and use interagency working groups to streamline and simplify Federal financial assistance administrative procedures, improve coordination of information sharing, and enhance the quality of information received by Federal agencies from recipients of Federal financial assistance. The Director may designate a lead agency and use interagency working groups to assist in carrying out responsibilities under this Act. Agencies must submit information for review regarding their implementation of the Act. The Director has the authority to exempt Federal agencies or programs if they do not have a significant number of financial assistance programs. A list of exempted agencies will be publicly available through OMB's Internet site. The Director will contract with the National Academy of Public Administration to evaluate the effectiveness of the Act, with input from various entities. The evaluation will assess the Act's effectiveness, agency performance, and coordination among different levels of government and organizations. SEC. 8. COLLECTION OF INFORMATION: The Act allows Federal agencies to gather necessary information for financial integrity reviews of activities receiving Federal assistance. 

SEC. 9. JUDICIAL REVIEW: Judicial review of compliance with the Act is not permitted, and no rights or benefits can be enforced through administrative or judicial actions.

SEC. 10. STATUTORY REQUIREMENTS: The Act does not override statutory requirements for Federal financial assistance programs.

SEC. 11. EFFECTIVE DATE AND SUNSET: The Act will take effect upon enactment and expire five years later. The Act was passed by the Senate on October 12, 1998, and attested by Secretary Gary Sisco.
